1) Most Operating Systems and Software store each pixel with numbers for Red, Green and Blue of 0 -> 255. This is because the max. number 1 byte (or 8 bits) can store is 255 (because 2 to the power of 8 - 1 is 255)
2) Many Image formats don't square root it anymore. If you have a camera, a RAW image wont either.
3) Square rooting wont have much of an impact on file size. People instead used 8-bit-color, which combines the R, G and B channels into one byte. This cannot be read as a normal number (For example, increasing the amount of Red in a pixel in 8-bit color will not raise it by one, look it up). using a square root would probably make it a float (= a number with decimal places: 0.1, 0.3123213, while numbers like 5 can be stored it is a waste due to the way they work, again, look it up, too much to explain)
4) Many sensors detect 30-bit-colour (10 bits for each channel, R, G and B). They normally downsize this to 24-bit-colour if the camera tells it to.

TL;DR, square rooting does not help file size, as storing their float value would use more space then just storing 8-bit-colour or 24-bit-colour.

A computationally efficient approximation (error at most about 1% for low x and y values) to sqrt(x^2/2+y^2/2) is the following...

(y+x)(7(x^2+y^2)+2*x*y)/(2*(5*(x^2+y^2)+6*x*y))

This uses 1 iteration of Halley's method with an initial guess of (x+y)/2, for the sqrt(x^2/2+y^2/2) and only requires integer arithmetic.

If you take the sum of squares it is always less than the strait sum (assumming strictly possitive values), and thereby the proposed "fix" would result in lower levels of brightness. We can see this from a simple geometric parallel: Taking the sum of squares is the same as what is being done in pythagoras theorem, where the first parts are the the shorter sides and the second is the longer side. We then have from the triangle inequality that the longest side in the triangle is upper bounded by the sum of the other sides, as the distance from a point in carthesian coordinates cannot be further than first going to some other point and then back to it (the shortest path is always the strait line).

This means that we should actually see the colors turn darker when such a "fix" is applied. The problem is more that just averaging the RGB values actually does this effectively to the brighness (as the brighness scale is seperate for each of the colors), and we instead need to perform the inverse operation, though this get more complicated if we did not start out with a pure Red/Green/Blue colors.

The problem is somewhat more complex, and has to do with the difference in type of coordinate system, when describing colors in terms of hue, intensity (brightness), and saturation. The transformations between these coordinate systems are non-linear, which means that we cannot perform an average with respect to hue and bightness in the RGB color scheme and expect to get the results we would have got if we had applied them in a coordinate system describing what we actually want.
What happens is somewhat similar to what would happen if you drew a strait line between 2 points on a sphere, and took the middle point. That point would be inside the sphere, and if we let brightness be described the distance from the centrum, we would then have that the new point (a mix between the 2 other color points) would be darker. The actual geometry of the correct color cooridinate system is slightly different, and we actually get such an effect both for brighness and saturation (this is why the yellow between the red and green shown in the video is somewhat more grey than it should be).

The normal solution is to change to a different color coordinate system before doing any digital color blending, and then change back to RGB before saving/sending it to the screen (since screens AND eyes works based on a RGB system).

While this video points out genuine issues in digital image processing, it oversimplifies the mathematics in misleading ways. It is not correct to claim that digital cameras record "the square root" of the detected light intensity. A camera that produces RAW images records the uncorrected light intensity detected by its linear image sensor. A camera that produces JPEG images uses a gamma correction curve designed for display on an LCD monitor viewed under subdued lighting. (This curve was modeled on the properties of earlier CRT monitors.) At no point is the square root of a light intensity involved in this process.

What's most misleading are the graphic images used in this video to illustrate the narrator's specious arguements. These images were all artificially generated as swatches of pure RGB colors, rather than real-world scenes photographed by a camera. Images of this type have no native gamma curve, aquare root or otherwise, and the borders between the rectangular shapes are unnaturatlly sharp. When image processing software is used to resize and smooth the artificial borders, color aliasing is produced by the sharp borders. It is the result of misapplying software designed for processing photograhic images (it's called "Photoshop" BTW) to manipulate artificially generated computer graphics that were not designed to be smoothly scaled down in size.

While the solution proposed by the video may appear esthetically more pleasing in this artificial case, it would not be an appropriate way to process real-world photographic images. "MinutePhysics" really showed how superficial its technical depth is with this video.

This particular example is iOS blurring an image in real time at the Operating System level of software, which has to be far more efficient than the applications running on top of the OS. Doing a simple add and divide is way more efficient than squaring twice, adding, dividing, then taking the square root. Luckily, in this case, this effect is performed by a pixel shader on the device's GPU, otherwise we would be paying a much higher computational cost for these blur effects. Still, the GPUs on mobile devices can't be run too fast because of thermal considerations, hence the more efficient blur implementation. The image editor(s) you are using are on the other hand applications running on top of the OS and furthermore do not have to run in real-time, and therefore can offer the gamma corrected formula without an unexpected performance hit.

I think the early natural implementations were not purposefully trying to save bits. Rather, the values stored were the values used by the CRT monitor, which has a log response because of the way it works (and for the same reason as film: each photon is randomly distributed over the pixel area, but hitting a molecule that's already been hit will not add anything. It is rarer and rarer for the next +1 to register).

The optimizing was done on the physical side long before computers came around: tuning the phosphor to have a gamma near 2. I recall reading in the Foley, VanDam, er al. textbook that a careful choice allows just-noticable-differences and not waste values on either end nor have jumps that could be visibly subdivided, with 250 steps. That is very close to the TV gamma but was not adjusted to better fit: they just used the voltage values of the display as-is, even though they already knew they could do better.

The reason for leaving it as the CRT already used it and not doing anything different, even to improve it, was to save computation.  It wastes space (or quality) by not using the optimum gamma.

Note that the log voltage level to drive a display was useful for analog TV, not because of saving storage in the same manner as digital, but to get the most useful values out of the linear signal.  Again, that pre-dates anything digital.

It is a shame that software doesn't blend correctly even though the hardware is powerful enough.  I recall when a 80386 (maxed out with 8MB of RAM), with no floating point hardware, was high end: we knew to transform to gamma=1 before doing arithmetic or blending.  OTOH, DKB-Trace (later named POV Ray) original textures were designed with gamma, and didn't look right if you rendered with gamma=1.

Normally, I don't comment on misinformation on the web, but this is just SO wrong in so many ways:

First, he says that the camera records "0 for no brightness and 1 for full brightness."

No, it doesn't. A CCD counts the number of photons that hit a sensor for as long as it's exposed. A 14 bit camera ranges from 0 to 16383, not 0-1. He's confusing the gamma curve with brighness levels (which the gamma curve adjusts.)

Second, cameras do not capture images; they capture light intensity data. Camera sensors most specifically ARE linear (Gamma 1).  You'll notice he talks about setting a gamma curve and "evening out the data" to use less in the brighter range to mimic vision. 

Third,  he says that "dark colors" are "sampled" with more data points and bright with less. This is exactly the opposite of what a CCD does. It's inherent in the linear nature of binary data capture. What the gamma curve does is adjust the linear "curve" from the CCD into a responsive curve more like the human eye.

In fact, MORE data is captured in the brightest ranges and significantly less in the darker. This is a conundrum for photographers, who have to "ETR" Expose to the Right in order to open up the blacks, and is precisely WHY the gamma adjustment has to be made.


Forth:  then he attributes the dark lines when blurring to "the camera's square rooting" which he claims is done to "save space."  (Over what? The 0 to 1 he claims is used?)

Nonsense. Square roots would have to be real numbers, instead of integers, and would therefore be at least TWICE the size as integer representation. Integers are used in the files.

But more to the point, after saying the problem comes from the camera (for all the wrong reasons) we learn that... you get the same effect with NO CAMERA AT ALL involved. His whole "cameras cause it because they are saving file space by square-rooting" simply falls flat on its face. If you open Photoshop and create a red square and a green square overlapping, you'll see the same thing. No square rooting; no camera involved. So his whole the-camera-is-at-fault premise is pure bunk.

The issue is that once the linear gamma (gamma 1) of RGB is converted to human vision equivalence (something less than one), blending using those darker values yields...ummm... darker values. Wow! Who'd have thought? 

RGB is a transmissive/additive light definition. Paint/ink/photos are reflective and subtractive. Look, take a tube of red paint, and mix it with green paint. Guess what? You don't get yellow, you get BROWN.  Just like he's complaining about.

RGB (transmissive/additive light) blending is best done in a linear gamma space, and that's what he's advocating for so poorly. (LightRoom does this behind the scenes.) But subtractive blending is done in a non-linear space.

So why does Photoshop do it that way by default? Because Photoshop is aimed at making (wait for it...) photos which are reflective/subtractive mixtures of ink on paper. You know: paint!

What's actually happening in Photoshop is that the adjacent colors are mixed at their same luminosity, just as if you were mixing the two shades of red and green paint. You'd get a brownish, and darker tone. They do that because it's PHOTOshop, and photos are made by mixing inks together.

Photoshop is not "doing it wrong" - it's doing it RIGHT! 

And, as he graciously points out, you can force Photoshop  to mix with linear gamma, if you're so inclined... but tell me the next time you see red and green paint together with a nice yellow line between them !

Finally, in case you feel the need to try the mix with linear gamma in Photoshop: linear gamma doesn't work well with sRGB, which is by definition an 8-bit file, as it will likely introduce banding, so using the "mix at gamma 1" in Photoshop should only be used on 16-bit images.

Frankly, this is all very old  news. What so interesting is how poorly and incorrectly he explained it all.

The thing is, it's arguably bad design to do this gamma correction during color blending/blurring in each application via a setting. That may be why even knowledgeable programmers are reluctant to do it, let alone enable it by default. It should be done when reading the image file, then all the mixing and blending should be done linearly, and then the reverse gamma correction should be applied to the result. Doing gamma correction during color blending would also make the program run slower -- color blending is often done on the GPU these days, and the hardware color blender even in modern GPUs is "fixed-function", i.e. it isn't freely programmable, it's only somewhat parameterizable, and it can only do linear blending (see https://www.opengl.org/sdk/docs/man/html/glBlendFunc.xhtml). You can do arbitrary non-linear blending in a pixel shader (a small user program that is run by the GPU in parallel for each pixel of the frame to compute its color), but that's still slower than the fixed-function blender, and it may require a large refactoring of your rendering pipeline code, so you may not be able to do that easily.

As mentioned, the right way to solve this problem is to apply ^(1/Gamma) to all pixel values of an input image as you're reading it, since common image formats like JPEG have already been gamma-corrected during creation, i.e. their pixel values correspond to (physical light intensity of the pixel)^Gamma. Then you would do all the color mixing and blending linearly, and then apply ^Gamma once to the final result pixel right before sending it to the display hardware -- which internally computes ^(1/Gamma) to get the actual physical brightness of the pixel on the display (this was due to physical properties of the screen on CRTs, and modern LCDs emulate it for backwards compatibility).

This is all supported in hardware these days: the sRGB texture format (since OpenGL 2.1) takes care of the gamma correction when reading images -- i.e. it computes texture value = (image pixel value)^(1/Gamma) when reading an image into a texture. Then you can blend multiple texture values linearly, i.e. just add/average them to obtain the result pixel which you write into the framebuffer. After that, the sRGB framebuffer format (GL_FRAMEBUFFER_SRGB, sine OpenGL 3) takes care of computing output pixel value = (framebuffer pixel value)^Gamma, which is sent to the display. I don't know which part of that pipeline common tools like Photoshop or GIMP get wrong (I'm not really an expert on this stuff either), but the solution proposed here ("Blend RGB colors using Gamma" setting in Photoshop) is not optimal.

The actual colourspace used is called sRGB and you can see a full description of the transform on wikipedia: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SRGB#Specification_of_the_transformation . The way it's defined is that it's linear at low intensities and then transitions to a curve with gamma of 2.4, but offset a bit so it's almost, but not quite completely unlike than if you had just used a gamma of 2.2 for the entire curve. The reason a lot of software takes the lazy approach is because, frankly, doing the correct thing means working in at least 16 bits per colour channel (or losing precision) and then you really start running into memory issues, or having to spend processor power on the transformation. Simply put, it's not worth it. You might have nicer blurring on your iphone, but you'll also have half the battery life.

As a concrete example, I tried turning on correct scaling for the images our users were uploading and that made the thumbnail generation take twice as much time, so we had to make do with the scaling used by everyone else.

Well, not exactly square and square root -- the gamma value is 2.2, so the functions are x^2.2 and x^(1/2.2).  But square and square root are close enough, for your illustration.

There's another issue, though, which undermines the point you are trying to make.  Color is also quantized to 256 levels per channel because of storage efficiency.  If you stored the de-gammaed values the values would either require more bits to store the colors with same visual fidelity or you would lose a lot of color fidelity on the darker colors (and gain undetectable fidelity in the bright colors).  This is one of the reasons Photoshop supports a 16 bits per channel mode, so that you can go ahead an convert into a de-gammaed mode, do all your true photon-space color transformations, convert back, and not worry about loss of fidelity.  Without this, you would basically get banding in the dark colors.  So what you are asking for is that images be stored in de-gammaed 16 bit .tiff format.  Which only the high-end pro apps really support.

This is a lot of work to do for "toy apps", whereas direct RGB value averaging is cheap, and produces very little color banding.
